entry.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
entry.content:
You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

Jekyll requires blog post files to be named according to the following format:

YEAR-MONTH-DAY-title.MARKUP

Where YEAR is a four-digit number, MONTH and DAY are both two-digit numbers, and MARKUP is the file extension representing the format used in the file. After that, include the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll Talk.

GIS Home

Geospatial Services Librarian

Taylor Hixson
Email Me
Subjects:Geographic Information Systems

NYUAD GIS workshops

Geographic Information Systems (GIS)

Geographic Information Systems (GIS) are any set of tools or technologies used to collect, integrate, store, edit, analyze, share, or display geographic information. GIS applications are tools that allow users to create interactive queries, analyze spatial information, edit data in maps, and present the results of all these operations.

Access GIS at NYUAD

Access Desktop GIS

  • GIS in the Center for Digital Scholarship
    NYUAD Library's Center for Digital Scholarships has two PCs with increased RAM and storage for students, faculty, and researchers to use for geospatial projects. The computers include the following software for geospatial projects:
      ArcGIS, including ArcGIS Pro
      QGIS
      GRASS GIS
      SketchUp
      GeoDa
      R/R Studio
      Python (IDLE)
      Google Earth Pro
  • Access QGIS at NYUAD Library
    QGIS is available in the library's instructional classroom (303) and the advanced media center (306). QGIS is a free and open-source software compatible with Mac, PC, and Linux
  • Access ArcGIS at NYUAD
    ArcGIS is available on all public PCs in the library. Scroll to ArcGIS in this spreadsheet to find all the places elsewhere on campus where ArcGIS is installed.
  • Access ArcGIS Pro at NYUAD Library
    ArcGIS Pro is available on the two GIS PCs in the Library's Center for Digital Scholarship. If requested, the Center for Academic Technology can provide ArcGIS Pro with any install of ArcGIS. ArcGIS Pro requires users to have an ArcGIS Online account. Email NYUAD librarian for geospatial data services or NYU Data Services for an NYU account.
  • Request an ArcGIS license
    The Center for Academic Technology provides free ArcGIS licenses to students, faculty, and researchers. E-mail nyuad.academictech@nyu.edu for a license. Students should include in the email their first and last name, netID, major (area of study), and operating system for all software requests.

Access Web GIS

  • ArcGIS Online, Story Maps & Survey123
    For access to the NYU ArcGIS Online organizational account--which includes Story Maps, Survey123 and Esri training--e-mail taylor.hixson@nyu.edu or data.services@nyu.edu to set up your account.
  • Access Carto at NYUAD
    Use your NYU email to create a free account.

Consulting Guidelines

Services provided

  • Our role is to facilitate your geospatial analysis within the realm of our supported software packages (i.e., ArcGIS, QGIS, Carto, ArcGIS Online, and Esri Story Maps). We can assist you with issues that you may encounter with respect to data finding (locating geospatial data), preparation (importing, merging, and cleaning data), analysis (geoprocessing), and results (understanding the formatting of the output). We can also help you select the best package for your task, interpret error messages, and locate documentation and further resources.

  • In addition to providing regularly scheduled software-specific tutorials, we can also help instructors by providing classroom presentations to introduce geospatial software.

  • Our role is to assist you with your analysis, rather than to conduct analyses for you. It is the researcher's responsibility to ensure that the research design, analysis, and programming are justified and appropriate for the discipline at hand.

Whom we can help

Consulting services are limited to current NYU students, faculty, and staff.

Types of assistance not covered by our service

  • One-on-one GIS/mapping tutoring and general inquiries about methodology and statistical topics

  • Assistance with projects of commercial nature or those involving classified information, non-disclosure agreements, related to or likely to be involved in litigation, etc.


Original work in this LibGuide is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

Spatial Data Resources

Geospatial Services Librarian

Taylor Hixson
Email Me
Subjects:Geographic Information Systems

NYU Spatial Data Repository

  • Spatial Data Repository
    The best starting place for finding geospatial data owned by NYU, created by NYU faculty and students, freely available online, and resources available from other universities.

Global Open Spatial Data

  • Natural Earth Data
    Natural Earth is a public domain map dataset available at 1:10m, 1:50m, and 1:110 million scales. Featuring tightly integrated vector and raster data, with Natural Earth you can make a variety of visually pleasing, well-crafted maps with cartography or GIS software.
  • Global Administrative Areas
    Download individual country administrative boundaries in multiple formats.
  • IPUMS International GIS
    IPUMS provides geographic information to facilitate cross-temporal and cross-national comparative analyses. Multiple census years are available for most countries in the database. Create a free account for best user experience. NOTE: Shapefiles distributed by IPUMS-International provide generalized boundaries and are not intended for precise geographical calculations.
  • Geofabrik
    Download OpenStreetMap data, including global places of interest and street networks. Updated regularly.
  • DIVA-GIS
    Free population, infrastructure, and land data by country.
  • Humanitarian Data Exchange
    Authoritative data resources, including spatial, from global humanitarian agencies and governments.
  • Global Land Cover Facility
    The GLCF is a center for land cover science with a focus on research using remotely sensed satellite data and products to access land cover change for local to global systems.
  • NASA Earth Data
    This application allows you to search, discover, visualize, refine, and access NASA Earth Observation data. Create a free account for best user experience.
  • Google Earth Engine Explorer
    Locate and download raster data from around the world. Best for when you need a small area rather than global scale. Allows basic analysis in the workspace before downloading. Create a free account for best user experience.
  • Global Forest Watch
    Find and download geospatial data related to global forest conservation and protection, including data about local and indigenous people, biodiversity, and potential natural and human threats to forests.
  • Geolode
    A catalog of websites that offer geospatial data.
  • Open Addresses
    An essential tool for free geocoding. Regional interest includes partial coverage in Dubai, Doha, and Kuwait.

NYU Spatial Data Resources and Databases

Helpful Tools

  • Epsg.io
    A database of coordinates systems used in maps worldwide.
  • Projection Wizard
    Projection Wizard is a web application that helps cartographers select an appropriate projection for their map.
  • Map Warper
    Georeference maps online. Can export any uploaded image type as GeoTIFF, KML, and even WMS or Tile layer to use in ArcGIS Online. Note: this resource should only be used for out of U.S. copyright maps and not for proprietary or NYU access only resources as it makes all contributions publicly available.
  • geojson.io
    This website allows users to import and convert a geoJSON to a number of downloadable spatial data types, including shapefile, kml, and csv, and vice versa. Additionally, draw custom shapes in the interface and export it in multiple geospatial file formats, including shapefile, geoJSON, csv, KML, and more.
  • GeoNames
    A free database that provides a latitude and longitude for more than 11 million places worldwide. An essential tool for geocoding and finding accurate placenames.
  • Color Brewer
    A helpful tool for choosing user-friendly map colors.
  • MapChart.net
    Need a simple map visual? Make one in minutes with Map Chart!
  • Map in seconds
    Have a spreadsheet with place names that you want to turn into a choropleth map? Paste your data into this website for a map in literally seconds! 600 city, regional, and country maps are available.

Original work in this LibGuide is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

Learn GIS

Geospatial Services Librarian

Taylor Hixson
Email Me
Subjects:Geographic Information Systems

Online Learning Resources

  • LinkedIn Learning GIS Playlist
    This playlist features LinkedIn Learning (previously Lynda.com) courses for learning GIS from the ground up, including courses about finding and using public data to getting started with a desktop GIS to making maps in Illustrator.
  • Esri Virtual Campus Courses
    Learn to use ArcGIS or ArcGIS Online products with Esri Virtual Campus Courses. The courses include anything from in-depth introductory tutorials to 5-minute briefs on performing a task.
    Email taylor.hixson@nyu.edu or data.services@nyu.edu for access to the web course catalog.
  • List of GIS Moocs
    Massive open online courses, or moocs, are courses available online instructed by academics or leaders in the field. Some moocs require payment or advanced registration but are often free.
  • QGIS User-Made Tutorials
  • Geospatial Data Abstraction Library (GDAL)
    The most approachable tutorial online for getting started with GDAL! This links to part one of a four part series. Note: if following this series using a PC, use " (double quotes) anywhere ' (single quotes) are used.
  • NYU NY learning resources
    Resources for regularly offered NYU NY Data Services' GIS workshops.

NYUAD workshop resources

The NYUAD Librarian for Geospatial Data Services offers a variety of drop-in workshops throughout the academic year. Resources from some of those workshops are available below. Visit the NYUAD Library event calendar to see all library workshops offered.

Instruction

Geospatial Services Librarian

Taylor Hixson
Email Me
Subjects:Geographic Information Systems

NYUAD GIS workshops

Class support for geospatial tools and concepts

The NYUAD Librarian for Geospatial Data Services regularly collaborates with faculty across the disciplines to offer integrated support for GIS learning. Such instruction often involves:

  • teaching or co-teaching customized in-class workshops for supported geospatial software, skills, or resources
  • working with instructors and professors to develop learner-centered assignments
  • consulting with students in small groups or one-on-one about using and finding geospatial resources for assignments
  • providing custom research guides and resources to support NYUAD courses

If you are interested in integrated course support for GIS, please reach out to the NYUAD Librarian for Geospatial Data Services for further questions or requests.

Cutomized group instruction

Any NYUAD community member may request a custom geospatial data or GIS workshop for NYUAD supported tools and services.

A minimum of three participants are required for a custom workshop. Email the NYUAD Librarian for Geospatial Data Services to further discuss workshop options and make arrangements. 

NYUAD workshop resources

Georeferencing

  • Fundamentals of georeferencing
  • Georeferencing toolbar
  • Georeference by entering specific x,y coordinates (When using this method, make sure to enter six digits past the decimal point, even if all six are zeroes, e.g., 90.000000)
  • Georeference a raster to a vector
  • Written tutorial with data: Geospatial historian georeferencing lesson
  • Video tutorial with data: LinkedIn Learning training video with data (see section 11)
  • MapWarper.net is an easy to use website for georeferencing and converting any image type to a fully georeferenced GeoTIFF usable in your projects. Consult the geospatial services librarian before deciding if this is the best georeferencing option for you.

Five steps for georeferencing maps:

  1. Figure out the projection. If it is not written on the map, try finding it with epsg.io or projection wizard.
  2. Find 6 or more points on the map that would be present in a modern day map (buildings, landmarks, rail stations, points of latitude and longitude)
  3. Download shapefile(s) that match the present-day areas or places of interest in the map. For example, download countries from gadm.org, naturalearthdata.com, or create your own control points.
  4. In ArcMap, specify the coordinate system used in the original map and/or reproject the shapefile(s) to match the projection used in the map.
  5. Follow the steps for georeferencing a raster to a vector.
  • Use this starter method in conjunction with other methods of georeferencing. For example, georeferencing to an Esri basemap or known x,y values on the map. However, always make sure to specify the correct coordinate system to reduce warping and improve accuracy of future analysis.

Spatial data resources

  • Spatial Data Repository
    NYU's source for geospatial data such as vector data (shapefiles) and raster data, which includes scanned maps. This resource also shows maps and data available to download from partner institutions.
  • Global Administrative Areas
    Download individual country administrative boundaries in multiple formats.
  • Natural Earth Data
    Natural Earth is a public domain map dataset available at 1:10m, 1:50m, and 1:110 million scales. Featuring tightly integrated vector and raster data, with Natural Earth you can make a variety of visually pleasing, well-crafted maps with cartography or GIS software.
  • IPUMS
    IPUMS provides census and survey data, including geospatial data, from around the world integrated across time and space. IPUMS integration and documentation makes it easy to study change, conduct comparative research, merge information across data types, and analyze individuals within family and community contexts.
  • DIVA-GIS
    Free population, infrastructure, and land data by country.

Scanned maps

Below are some resources that provided historical maps and atlases.

    Unique maps from around the world available for free download, typically as a .jpg.
  • Old Maps Online
  • Ebook Central
    Search for "atlas" and an area of interest to find atlases with unique maps for course assignments

Five steps for georeferencing in desktop GIS:

  1. Figure out the map's projection, or coordinate system (see coordinate system resources below). If the coordinate system is not written on the map, try finding it with epsg.io or projection wizard.
  2. Find 6 or more points on the map that would be present in a modern day map (buildings, landmarks, rail stations, points of latitude and longitude)
  3. Download shapefile(s) from gadm.org that match the present-day country or countries in the map.
  4. In the GIS, specify the coordinate system and/or reproject the shapefile(s) to match the projection used in the map.
  5. Follow the steps for georeferencing a raster to a vector.

IPUMS integration and documentation makes it easy to study change, conduct comparative research, merge information across data types, and analyze individuals within family and community contexts.

Note: The resources on this page were put together by NYU NY Data Services. For questions, comments, or concerns about the content, contact NYU NY Data Services. Visit their GIS guide for further resources and guidance.

If you are currently at NYUAD, the Geospatial Services Librarian can assist with accessing the resources.

Geospatial Analysis & File Conversion

  Geospatial Analysis & File Conversion: Understanding basic possibilities of GIS

  • GIS/Mapping Tools and Services
    Learn the definition of GIS, different GIS applications available at NYU, and GIS data sources
  • How to Get Started with ArcGIS Online
    ESRI Academy course that covers adding layers to a map, styling layers, configuring pop-ups, sharing a map as an app, and editing item details
  • How to Clip Shapefile Features to a Study Area in ArcMap
    Using the clipping tool within the ArcMap toolbox to select parts from a larger shapefile
  • How to Clip Shapefile Features to a Study Area in QGIS
    Using the clip tool within QGIS to select parts from a larger shapefile.
  • How to Create a Single Buffer around Shapefile Features in ArcMap
    Generating buffers and other areas around map features to perform analysis
  • How to Create a Single Buffer around Shapefile Features in QGIS
    Generating buffers and other areas around map features to perform analysis
  • How to Dissolve Shapefiles in ArcMap
    Aggregating or eliminating GIS layers within ArcMap
  • Introduction to ArcGIS (ArcMap)
    Become familiar with ESRI's desktop software and basic GIS concepts

Data Cleaning and Management

  Data Cleaning & Management: Transforming and manipulating data for GIS analysis

  • How to Merge Shapefiles in ArcMap
    A guide to merging shapefiles and managing GIS projects
  • How to Merge Shapefiles in QGIS
    A guide to merging shapefiles for GIS projects
  • How to Join Data in ArcMap (basic Table and Spatial Joins)
    Joining two datasets together based on a shared ID or overlapping spatial area
  • How to Join Data in QGIS (basic Table and Spatial Joins)
    Joining two datasets together based on a shared ID or overlapping spatial area
  • Open Refine
    A tool for working with messy data, cleaning it, transforming it from one format into another, extending it with web services
  • Data Cleaning Using Open Refine
    Learn an open-source tool for fast clean up of tabular data in preparation for analysis
  • DataWrangler Alpha
    A simple application to clean data and export data into text files.
  • Data Cleaning for GIS
    Develop essential strategies for cleaning data in preparation for visualization and analysis with GIS software

Geospatial Visualization

  Geospatial Visualization: Approaches to creating maps and illuminating GIS data

  • How to Get Started with ESRI StoryMaps
    ESRI Academy course that covers the basics of creating a StoryMap, adding content to it, and publishing it
  • Data Visualization with Tableau
    An introduction of basic principles of data visualization with Tableau
  • Color Brewer
    Color Brewer generates color swatches for sequential, diverging, and qualitative maps.
  • Cesium
    Cesium is a JavaScript library for creating 3D globes and 2D maps in a web browser without a plugin. It uses WebGL for hardware-accelerated graphics, and is cross-platform, cross-browser, and tuned for dynamic-data visualization. Cesium is open source under the Apache 2.0 license. It is free for commercial and non-commercial use.

Geocoding

  Geocoding: Generating latitude and longitude coordinates to reference data in GIS software

  • How to Geocode Data in ArcMap
    Establishing a geocoding tool and optimizing results in ArcMap
  • How to Geocode Data in QGIS
    Geocoding addresses in QGIS
  • Geocode by Awesome Table
    Geocode by Awesome Table is a Google Sheets add-on that allows users to derive coordinates for structured data. The add-on calls from the Google Maps API.
  • Address Geocoding with ArcGIS
    ESRI Academy course that covers the mechanics of preparing data to be geocoded within ArcMap
  • HamsterMap
    Geocode locations from decimal degree format into standard GIS format
  • Texas A&M Geocoding Services
    Texas A&M Geoservices offers geocoding that is the result of years of work. If you have a large-scale dataset, you may want to enlist this service.

Georeferencing

  Georeferencing: Ascribing location data to scanned images of historic maps

  • NYPL Map Warper
    NYPL Map Warper is a tool for digitally aligning ("rectifying") historical maps from the NYPL's collections to match today's maps. Visitors can browse already rectified maps or assist the NYPL by aligning a map.
  • David Rumsey Georeferencer
    Georeferencer from the David Rumsey collection at Stanford University is an application that allows users to overlay historic maps on modern maps or other historic maps. The overlaid maps reveal changes over time and enable map analysis and discovery.
  • Georeferencing Raster Data Using ArcGIS
    An ESRI Academy course designed to introduce the concepts and strategies of georeferencing raster images

Skills and resources

Georeferencing
  • Fundamentals of georeferencing
  • Georeferencing toolbar
  • Georeference by entering specific x,y coordinates (When using this method, make sure to enter six digits past the decimal point, even if all six are zeroes, e.g., 90.000000)
  • Georeference a raster to a vector
  • Written tutorial with data: Geospatial historian georeferencing lesson
  • Video tutorial with data: LinkedIn Learning training video with data (see section 11)
  • MapWarper.net is an easy to use website for georeferencing and converting any image type to a fully georeferenced GeoTIFF usable in your projects. Consult the geospatial services librarian before deciding if this is the best georeferencing option for you.
Five steps for georeferencing maps:
  1. Figure out the projection. If it is not written on the map, try finding it with epsg.io or projection wizard.
  2. Find 6 or more points on the map that would be present in a modern day map (buildings, landmarks, rail stations, points of latitude and longitude)
  3. Download shapefile(s) that match the present-day areas or places of interest in the map. For example, download countries from gadm.org, naturalearthdata.com, or create your own control points.
  4. In ArcMap, specify the coordinate system used in the original map and/or reproject the shapefile(s) to match the projection used in the map.
  5. Follow the steps for georeferencing a raster to a vector.
  • Use this starter method in conjunction with other methods of georeferencing. For example, georeferencing to an Esri basemap or known x,y values on the map. However, always make sure to specify the correct coordinate system to reduce warping and improve accuracy of future analysis.

  • Global Administrative Areas
    Download individual country administrative boundaries in multiple formats.
  • Natural Earth Data
    Natural Earth is a public domain map dataset available at 1:10m, 1:50m, and 1:110 million scales. Featuring tightly integrated vector and raster data, with Natural Earth you can make a variety of visually pleasing, well-crafted maps with cartography or GIS software.
  • Geofabrik
    Download OpenStreetMap data, including global places of interest and street networks. Updated regularly.
  • Old Maps Online
    Search for scanned maps available from libraries, archives, and other resource providers around the world.

    IPUMS provides census and survey data, including geospatial data, from around the world integrated across time and space. IPUMS integration and documentation makes it easy to study change, conduct comparative research, merge information across data types, and analyze individuals within family and community contexts.

This workshop was led by Taylor Hixson, NYUAD Librarian for Geospatial Data Services, on 30 October 2019 for the NYUAD student chapter of the American Society of Civil Engineers. Use this guide to access resources from the workshop and as a further resource for learning about GIS in civil engineering.

Key Scholarship Resources

Below are three good resources that describe geographic information systems and geospatial data in the context of civil engineering.

David  A. Holdstock. “Basis of Geographic Information Systems (GIS).” Journal of Computing in Civil Engineering, vol. 12, no. 1, Jan. 1998, p. 4

Jack Dangermond, and Adena Schutzberg. “Engineering, Geographic Information Systems, and Databases: A New Frontier.” Journal of Computing in Civil Engineering, vol. 12, no. 3, July 1998, p. 2.

Hassan A. Karimi. “Data Acquisition through Emerging High-Resolution Satellite Imagery.” Journal of Computing in Civil Engineering, vol. 12, no. 3, July 1998, p. 3.

 

  • Journal of Computing in Civil Engineering: GIS Search
    Link to a search for GIS within the Journal of Computing in Civil Engineering since 1995.
  • ASCE Library
    The ASCE Library is a digital library that provides access to a collection of civil engineering content. It contains articles from ASCE journals, papers from conference proceedings, and e-books and standards.

Faculty Consulting

Geospatial Services Librarian

Taylor Hixson
Email Me
Subjects:Geographic Information Systems

NYUAD faculty geospatial consulting services

Services Provided

  • Prepping data for mapping or analysis (geocoding, joining data, data cleaning, reprojecting, etc.)
  • Geoprocessing
  • Conversion of geospatial data formats or extracting attribute tables
  • Geospatial data and project management
  • Creating Story Maps or ArcGIS Online web apps
  • Setting up Survey123 surveys for data collection
  • Heads-up digitizing of scanned maps
  • Creating maps for publication (acknowledgement required)
  • Creating Leaflet maps to embed on websites (website must already exist or be underdevelopment)
  • Developing training and education resources for research assistants
  • Archiving original geospatial research data in the NYU Spatial Data Repository.

It is the researcher's responsibility to ensure that the research design, analysis, and programming are justified and appropriate for the discipline at hand. Further details about the NYUAD Geospatial Services.

Services not provided

  • Debugging code
  • Software engineering or development
  • Interpretation of analysis or results
  • Database management
  • Large-scale, unsupervised machine learning
  • One-on-one GIS/mapping tutoring and general inquiries about methodology and statistical topics
  • Assistance with projects of commercial nature or those involving classified information, non-disclosure agreements, related to or likely to be involved in litigation, etc.

Community served

Current NYUAD faculty only. 

All other communities may schedule appointments and consult with the Geospatial Services Librarian about capstone assistance, finding data, choosing packages and software, interpreting errors, and other inquiries outlined on the NYU Data Services Consulting guidelines located on the NYUAD GIS Home page.

Scheduling consulting services

Faculty are required to schedule a preliminary appointment with the geospatial data services librarian to determine the approximate hours required and feasibility of the suggested work before scheduling consulting hours. Email the librarian or schedule an appointment.

The Geospatial Data Services Librarian offers 8 hours each week dedicated to working on faculty research. Those hours are not inclusive of other tasks related to instruction, finding resources, geoprocessing task run time, which a faculty member may request in addition to consulting hours. On a case-by-case basis, faculty members requiring more hours or long-term assistance may discuss research partnerships with the librarian and NYUAD Center for Digital Scholarship.

entry.summary: Return to Old Guides Online GIS Home - Geographic Information Systems - Research Guides at New York University Skip to main content NYU Libraries Research Guides Abu Dhabi Library Geographic Information Systems GIS Home Search this Guide Search Geographic Information Systems: GIS Home Geographic information systems and spatial data resources for the NYU Abu Dhabi community. GIS Home Spatial Data Resources Learn GIS Instruction Toggle Dropdown Boundaries: CSTS-UH 1021EQ DHS: CDAD-UH-1033Q Geospatial Guidance WIDH: Spatial Humanities ASCE SIG <a title="" class="" href="javascript:void(0);" style="font-style:italic;"onclick="jQuery('html, body').animate({ scrollTop: jQuery('#s-lg-page-section-6686905').offset().top }, 750);" aria-label="Faculty Consulting" > Faculty Consulting </a> GIS Home Geospatial Services Librarian Taylor Hixson Email Me Schedule Appointment Subjects:Geographic Information Systems NYUAD GIS workshops Geographic Information Systems (GIS) Geographic Information Systems (GIS) are any set of tools or technologies used to collect, integrate, store, edit, analyze, share, or display geographic information. GIS applications are tools that allow users to create interactive queries, analyze spatial information, edit data in maps, and present the results of all these operations. Access GIS at NYUAD Access Desktop GIS GIS in the Center for Digital Scholarship NYUAD Library's Center for Digital Scholarships has two PCs with increased RAM and storage for students, faculty, and researchers to use for geospatial projects. The computers include the following software for geospatial projects: ArcGIS, including ArcGIS Pro QGIS GRASS GIS SketchUp GeoDa R/R Studio Python (IDLE) Google Earth Pro Access QGIS at NYUAD Library QGIS is available in the library's instructional classroom (303) and the advanced media center (306). QGIS is a free and open-source software compatible with Mac, PC, and Linux Access ArcGIS at NYUAD ArcGIS is available on all public PCs in the library. Scroll to ArcGIS in this spreadsheet to find all the places elsewhere on campus where ArcGIS is installed. Access ArcGIS Pro at NYUAD Library ArcGIS Pro is available on the two GIS PCs in the Library's Center for Digital Scholarship. If requested, the Center for Academic Technology can provide ArcGIS Pro with any install of ArcGIS. ArcGIS Pro requires users to have an ArcGIS Online account. Email NYUAD librarian for geospatial data services or NYU Data Services for an NYU account. Request an ArcGIS license The Center for Academic Technology provides free ArcGIS licenses to students, faculty, and researchers. E-mail nyuad.academictech@nyu.edu for a license. Students should include in the email their first and last name, netID, major (area of study), and operating system for all software requests. Access Web GIS ArcGIS Online, Story Maps & Survey123 For access to the NYU ArcGIS Online organizational account--which includes Story Maps, Survey123 and Esri training--e-mail taylor.hixson@nyu.edu or data.services@nyu.edu to set up your account. Access Carto at NYUAD Use your NYU email to create a free account. Consulting Guidelines Services provided Our role is to facilitate your geospatial analysis within the realm of our supported software packages (i.e., ArcGIS, QGIS, Carto, ArcGIS Online, and Esri Story Maps). We can assist you with issues that you may encounter with respect to data finding (locating geospatial data), preparation (importing, merging, and cleaning data), analysis (geoprocessing), and results (understanding the formatting of the output). We can also help you select the best package for your task, interpret error messages, and locate documentation and further resources. In addition to providing regularly scheduled software-specific tutorials, we can also help instructors by providing classroom presentations to introduce geospatial software. Our role is to assist you with your analysis, rather than to conduct analyses for you. It is the researcher's responsibility to ensure that the research design, analysis, and programming are justified and appropriate for the discipline at hand. Whom we can help Consulting services are limited to current NYU students, faculty, and staff. Types of assistance not covered by our service One-on-one GIS/mapping tutoring and general inquiries about methodology and statistical topics Assistance with projects of commercial nature or those involving classified information, non-disclosure agreements, related to or likely to be involved in litigation, etc. Original work in this LibGuide is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License. Global Open Spatial Data Natural Earth Data Natural Earth is a public domain map dataset available at 1:10m, 1:50m, and 1:110 million scales. Featuring tightly integrated vector and raster data, with Natural Earth you can make a variety of visually pleasing, well-crafted maps with cartography or GIS software. Global Administrative Areas Download individual country administrative boundaries in multiple formats. IPUMS International GIS IPUMS provides geographic information to facilitate cross-temporal and cross-national comparative analyses. Multiple census years are available for most countries in the database. Create a free account for best user experience. NOTE: Shapefiles distributed by IPUMS-International provide generalized boundaries and are not intended for precise geographical calculations. Geofabrik Download OpenStreetMap data, including global places of interest and street networks. Updated regularly. DIVA-GIS Free population, infrastructure, and land data by country. Humanitarian Data Exchange Authoritative data resources, including spatial, from global humanitarian agencies and governments. Global Land Cover Facility The GLCF is a center for land cover science with a focus on research using remotely sensed satellite data and products to access land cover change for local to global systems. NASA Earth Data This application allows you to search, discover, visualize, refine, and access NASA Earth Observation data. Create a free account for best user experience. Google Earth Engine Explorer Locate and download raster data from around the world. Best for when you need a small area rather than global scale. Allows basic analysis in the workspace before downloading. Create a free account for best user experience. Global Forest Watch Find and download geospatial data related to global forest conservation and protection, including data about local and indigenous people, biodiversity, and potential natural and human threats to forests. Geolode A catalog of websites that offer geospatial data. Open Addresses An essential tool for free geocoding. Regional interest includes partial coverage in Dubai, Doha, and Kuwait. NYU Spatial Data Resources and Databases Helpful Tools Epsg.io A database of coordinates systems used in maps worldwide. Projection Wizard Projection Wizard is a web application that helps cartographers select an appropriate projection for their map. Map Warper Georeference maps online. Can export any uploaded image type as GeoTIFF, KML, and even WMS or Tile layer to use in ArcGIS Online. Note: this resource should only be used for out of U.S. copyright maps and not for proprietary or NYU access only resources as it makes all contributions publicly available. geojson.io This website allows users to import and convert a geoJSON to a number of downloadable spatial data types, including shapefile, kml, and csv, and vice versa. Additionally, draw custom shapes in the interface and export it in multiple geospatial file formats, including shapefile, geoJSON, csv, KML, and more. GeoNames A free database that provides a latitude and longitude for more than 11 million places worldwide. An essential tool for geocoding and finding accurate placenames. Color Brewer A helpful tool for choosing user-friendly map colors. MapChart.net Need a simple map visual? Make one in minutes with Map Chart! Map in seconds Have a spreadsheet with place names that you want to turn into a choropleth map? Paste your data into this website for a map in literally seconds! 600 city, regional, and country maps are available. Use the Project Raster tool in ArcMap to reproject as needed. Instructions: Creating new shapefiles Instructions: Aligning shapefile edges Do your shapefile borders and edges have gaps and overlaps? Follow these instructions to create cleaner, neater, more accurate shapefiles. Editing and adding new features with the Editor toolbar Tour of the Editor toolbar and windows Video and tutorial: LinkedIn Learning video with data Video: Overview of adding Points, Lines, Polygons Video: Create features Video: Snapping to features Merge parts of a shapefile in Editor Video: Merge parts of a shapefile in Editor Video: Editing vertices Video: Editing polygons Video: Fix overlaps and gaps in polygons to align edges Make a hole (or a donut) in a polygon Exporting data or event layers as new shapefiles or geodatabases Exporting features instructions A quick tour exporting data Video: How to export a new layer Georeferencing Fundamentals of georeferencing Georeferencing toolbar Georeference by entering specific x,y coordinates (When using this method, make sure to enter six digits past the decimal point, even if all six are zeroes, e.g., 90.000000) Georeference a raster to a vector Written tutorial with data: Geospatial historian georeferencing lesson Video tutorial with data: LinkedIn Learning training video with data (see section 11) MapWarper.net is an easy to use website for georeferencing and converting any image type to a fully georeferenced GeoTIFF usable in your projects. Consult the geospatial services librarian before deciding if this is the best georeferencing option for you. Five steps for georeferencing maps: Figure out the projection. If it is not written on the map, try finding it with epsg.io or projection wizard. Find 6 or more points on the map that would be present in a modern day map (buildings, landmarks, rail stations, points of latitude and longitude) Download shapefile(s) that match the present-day areas or places of interest in the map. For example, download countries from gadm.org, naturalearthdata.com, or create your own control points. In ArcMap, specify the coordinate system used in the original map and/or reproject the shapefile(s) to match the projection used in the map. Follow the steps for georeferencing a raster to a vector. Use this starter method in conjunction with other methods of georeferencing. For example, georeferencing to an Esri basemap or known x,y values on the map. However, always make sure to specify the correct coordinate system to reduce warping and improve accuracy of future analysis. Spatial data resources Spatial Data Repository NYU's source for geospatial data such as vector data (shapefiles) and raster data, which includes scanned maps. This resource also shows maps and data available to download from partner institutions. Global Administrative Areas Download individual country administrative boundaries in multiple formats. Natural Earth Data Natural Earth is a public domain map dataset available at 1:10m, 1:50m, and 1:110 million scales. Featuring tightly integrated vector and raster data, with Natural Earth you can make a variety of visually pleasing, well-crafted maps with cartography or GIS software. IPUMS IPUMS provides census and survey data, including geospatial data, from around the world integrated across time and space. IPUMS integration and documentation makes it easy to study change, conduct comparative research, merge information across data types, and analyze individuals within family and community contexts. DIVA-GIS Free population, infrastructure, and land data by country. Scanned maps Below are some resources that provided historical maps and atlases. Border and Migration Studies Online Library database that includes maps and other documentation related to the creation of borders. Qatar Digital Library Search for and download high-quality regional maps David Rumsey Map Collection Perry-Castañeda Library Map Collection Unique maps from around the world available for free download, typically as a .jpg. Instructions: Using MapWarper.net to georeference Five steps for georeferencing in desktop GIS: Figure out the map's projection, or coordinate system (see coordinate system resources below). If the coordinate system is not written on the map, try finding it with epsg.io or projection wizard. Find 6 or more points on the map that would be present in a modern day map (buildings, landmarks, rail stations, points of latitude and longitude) Download shapefile(s) from gadm.org that match the present-day country or countries in the map. In the GIS, specify the coordinate system and/or reproject the shapefile(s) to match the projection used in the map. Follow the steps for georeferencing a raster to a vector. Geospatial Analysis & File Conversion   Geospatial Analysis & File Conversion: Understanding basic possibilities of GIS GIS/Mapping Tools and Services Learn the definition of GIS, different GIS applications available at NYU, and GIS data sources How to Get Started with ArcGIS Online ESRI Academy course that covers adding layers to a map, styling layers, configuring pop-ups, sharing a map as an app, and editing item details How to Clip Shapefile Features to a Study Area in ArcMap Using the clipping tool within the ArcMap toolbox to select parts from a larger shapefile How to Clip Shapefile Features to a Study Area in QGIS Using the clip tool within QGIS to select parts from a larger shapefile. How to Create a Single Buffer around Shapefile Features in ArcMap Generating buffers and other areas around map features to perform analysis How to Create a Single Buffer around Shapefile Features in QGIS Generating buffers and other areas around map features to perform analysis How to Dissolve Shapefiles in ArcMap Aggregating or eliminating GIS layers within ArcMap Introduction to ArcGIS (ArcMap) Become familiar with ESRI's desktop software and basic GIS concepts Data Cleaning and Management   Data Cleaning & Management: Transforming and manipulating data for GIS analysis How to Merge Shapefiles in ArcMap A guide to merging shapefiles and managing GIS projects How to Merge Shapefiles in QGIS A guide to merging shapefiles for GIS projects How to Join Data in ArcMap (basic Table and Spatial Joins) Joining two datasets together based on a shared ID or overlapping spatial area How to Join Data in QGIS (basic Table and Spatial Joins) Joining two datasets together based on a shared ID or overlapping spatial area Open Refine A tool for working with messy data, cleaning it, transforming it from one format into another, extending it with web services Data Cleaning Using Open Refine Learn an open-source tool for fast clean up of tabular data in preparation for analysis DataWrangler Alpha A simple application to clean data and export data into text files. Data Cleaning for GIS Develop essential strategies for cleaning data in preparation for visualization and analysis with GIS software Geospatial Visualization   Geospatial Visualization: Approaches to creating maps and illuminating GIS data How to Get Started with ESRI StoryMaps ESRI Academy course that covers the basics of creating a StoryMap, adding content to it, and publishing it Data Visualization with Tableau An introduction of basic principles of data visualization with Tableau Color Brewer Color Brewer generates color swatches for sequential, diverging, and qualitative maps. Cesium Cesium is a JavaScript library for creating 3D globes and 2D maps in a web browser without a plugin. It uses WebGL for hardware-accelerated graphics, and is cross-platform, cross-browser, and tuned for dynamic-data visualization. Cesium is open source under the Apache 2.0 license. It is free for commercial and non-commercial use. Geocoding   Geocoding: Generating latitude and longitude coordinates to reference data in GIS software How to Geocode Data in ArcMap Establishing a geocoding tool and optimizing results in ArcMap How to Geocode Data in QGIS Geocoding addresses in QGIS Geocode by Awesome Table Geocode by Awesome Table is a Google Sheets add-on that allows users to derive coordinates for structured data. The add-on calls from the Google Maps API. Address Geocoding with ArcGIS ESRI Academy course that covers the mechanics of preparing data to be geocoded within ArcMap HamsterMap Geocode locations from decimal degree format into standard GIS format Texas A&M Geocoding Services Texas A&M Geoservices offers geocoding that is the result of years of work. If you have a large-scale dataset, you may want to enlist this service. Georeferencing   Georeferencing: Ascribing location data to scanned images of historic maps NYPL Map Warper NYPL Map Warper is a tool for digitally aligning ("rectifying") historical maps from the NYPL's collections to match today's maps. Visitors can browse already rectified maps or assist the NYPL by aligning a map. David Rumsey Georeferencer Georeferencer from the David Rumsey collection at Stanford University is an application that allows users to overlay historic maps on modern maps or other historic maps. The overlaid maps reveal changes over time and enable map analysis and discovery. Use this guide to access resources from the workshop and as a further resource for learning about GIS in civil engineering. Written guide to workshop Workshop data Workshop slides Key Data Resources Digital Elevation Models Link to digital elevation models available in the NYU Spatial Data Repository. USGS Earth Explorer Google Earth Engine Explorer Locate and download raster data from around the world. Best for when you need a small area rather than global scale. Allows basic analysis in the workspace before downloading. Create a free account for best user experience. Key Scholarship Resources Below are three good resources that describe geographic information systems and geospatial data in the context of civil engineering. David  A. Holdstock. “Basis of Geographic Information Systems (GIS).” Journal of Computing in Civil Engineering, vol. 12, no. 1, Jan. 1998, p. 4 Jack Dangermond, and Adena Schutzberg. “Engineering, Geographic Information Systems, and Databases: A New Frontier.” Journal of Computing in Civil Engineering, vol. 12, no. 3, July 1998, p. 2. Hassan A. Karimi. “Data Acquisition through Emerging High-Resolution Satellite Imagery.” Journal of Computing in Civil Engineering, vol. 12, no. 3, July 1998, p. 3.   Journal of Computing in Civil Engineering: GIS Search Link to a search for GIS within the Journal of Computing in Civil Engineering since 1995. ASCE Library The ASCE Library is a digital library that provides access to a collection of civil engineering content. It contains articles from ASCE journals, papers from conference proceedings, and e-books and standards. Web of Science citations analysis for GIS AND "civil engineering" This links to a citation analysis of GIS AND "civil engineering" exported from Web of Science. Faculty Consulting Geospatial Services Librarian Taylor Hixson Email Me Schedule Appointment Subjects:Geographic Information Systems NYUAD faculty geospatial consulting services Services Provided Prepping data for mapping or analysis (geocoding, joining data, data cleaning, reprojecting, etc.) Geoprocessing Conversion of geospatial data formats or extracting attribute tables Geospatial data and project management Creating Story Maps or ArcGIS Online web apps Setting up Survey123 surveys for data collection Heads-up digitizing of scanned maps Creating maps for publication (acknowledgement required) Creating Leaflet maps to embed on websites (website must already exist or be underdevelopment) Developing training and education resources for research assistants Archiving original geospatial research data in the NYU Spatial Data Repository. It is the researcher's responsibility to ensure that the research design, analysis, and programming are justified and appropriate for the discipline at hand. Further details about the NYUAD Geospatial Services. Services not provided Debugging code Software engineering or development Interpretation of analysis or results Database management Large-scale, unsupervised machine learning One-on-one GIS/mapping tutoring and general inquiries about methodology and statistical topics Assistance with projects of commercial nature or those involving classified information, non-disclosure agreements, related to or likely to be involved in litigation, etc. Community served Current NYUAD faculty only.  All other communities may schedule appointments and consult with the Geospatial Services Librarian about capstone assistance, finding data, choosing packages and software, interpreting errors, and other inquiries outlined on the NYU Data Services Consulting guidelines located on the NYUAD GIS Home page. Scheduling consulting services Faculty are required to schedule a preliminary appointment with the geospatial data services librarian to determine the approximate hours required and feasibility of the suggested work before scheduling consulting hours. Email the librarian or schedule an appointment. The Geospatial Data Services Librarian offers 8 hours each week dedicated to working on faculty research. Those hours are not inclusive of other tasks related to instruction, finding resources, geoprocessing task run time, which a faculty member may request in addition to consulting hours. On a case-by-case basis, faculty members requiring more hours or long-term assistance may discuss research partnerships with the librarian and NYUAD Center for Digital Scholarship.
